Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the parent should provide guidance
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: The customer asks about the delivery status, while a delivery issue arises, such as a delayed or misplaced package
Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, watching my daughter fidget with her spoon, reminding her gently to say “please” when asking for more cereal. I wanted to be patient, to show her how important it is to speak kindly and wait her turn. Just as I was about to praise her for remembering, my phone buzzed with a message from a customer. Their package was delayed—again. I could feel the tension rising as I read their frustrated words, demanding an update. I knew I had to respond quickly and professionally, to reassure them and keep my job secure. But my daughter was looking up at me, waiting for my attention, needing my guidance. I felt torn, my mind pulled in two directions—one part wanting to be the calm, attentive parent, the other needing to be the reliable, courteous delivery person. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which role to answer first, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
